subject: Public Speaking
title: Printing Press and the Decline of Memory
description: A 60-second lesson on Printing Press and the Decline of Memory.

hook.text: When Gutenberg printed his first Bible in 1455, he didn't just change reading. He changed speaking.

buildup.text: Before print, orators memorized everything. Audiences expected speakers to perform from memory for hours.

discovery.text: Printed notes meant speakers could read. Memory â€” once the crown jewel of rhetoric â€” became optional.

twist.text: Written pamphlets also let ideas spread without a speaker present. Persuasion no longer required a stage.

climax.text: The printing press split oratory from writing for the first time. Two separate arts with separate rules.

punchline.text: Print freed ideas from the speaker's memory.

quiz.question: How did the printing press change public speaking?
options: It made memorization less essential and separated writing from oratory
